I think permanent branching could be done in a neat way.  For 
example: There is a war between old, pagan barbarians and a cleric-
led proselytizing army.  Pick one to side with, fight say three 
levels.  If you withdraw, you close off the possibility of playing 
through either of the two sides.  Then, depending on which you sided 
with, you come to a final stage that is the same.  Let me show:

          Learn of Conflict
    Barbarian     |     Cleric
    Barbarian  Neither  Cleric
    Barbarian     |     Cleric
           Siege Castle      

Now, if you side with the barbarians, when you come to siege the 
castle, a barbarian horde from the northern steppes will cut off the 
castle's reinforcements.  But if you side with the clerics, you will 
have a small squad helping you, which due to its campaign-outfitting, 
will provide you with some food and potions as well.

So this would work like this:

Level 0: LoC  Exits: B1, C1, Neither
Level 1: LoC (Backed Out)  Exits: Neither
Level 2: B1   Exits: Level 1, B2
Level 3: B2   Exits: B1, B3
Level 4: B3   Exits: CastleB
Level 5: CastleB  Exits: B3 (When all foes dead, automatically win, 
go to Cleared Castle)
Level 6: C1   Exits: Level 1, C2
Level 7: C2
..
Level 9: CastleC  Exits: C3 (When all foes dead, ...)
Level 10: Neither  Exits: Level 1, CastleN
Level 11: CastleN Exits (...)
Level 12: Cleared Castle  Exits (only forward)

Some other ideas:
An assassination mission.  Put all of the starting team spots in an 
area with faerie attacks of high power (so all team members are 
frozen).  Enclose this area.  Now put a thief outside of that, an NPC 
thief.  The level has a lot of enemies, too many for the thief to 
beat, but one low level named character.  Kill that guy, the level is 
automatically won.  This would be a level that emphasized stealth, 
avoidance, and tactical bursts.

Keep the town guarding hub, but have the other missions around it 
less cheesy.  Make each of them two or three levels long.  But make 
it so that when you clear any one of them, that's enough to trigger 
the next plot moment -- thus you have to "choose" again.  

Have some nice exploration stuff... maybe you get marooned in an area 
and need to figure out where to go next, and just get to wander four 
or five levels for a bit.

Level 5: C1
